text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text below a full-width horizontal miniature, all enclosed within a red pen-drawn border. Wide blank margins surround the framed block of image plus text.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textualis with cursive influences; professional book hand with regular line spacing, extensive use of abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Deep blue ground unifies the scene; red is reserved for framing and selective drapery accents; green denotes the bishop’s vestments and conveys ecclesiastical authority. White is layered for highlights on robes. The palette is applied in flat, even layers with minimal tonal gradation. Original pigments are well preserved with little fading.

features: Figures arranged in a horizontal procession
Central bishop flanked by clerics on either side
Empty space at far right balances crucified figure at left
Uniform figure scale across the scene

decorative_elements: Red ink border framing both miniature and text

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine brown ink outlines executed with a quill pen; slight variation in stroke weight defines contours
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal shading with flat color; occasional light hatching in drapery folds for subtle modelling
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: No true linear perspective; shallow recession indicated only by overlapping of figures and platform

content_theme.scene_description: A single horizontal scene depicts four figures before an empty bier. At far left a nearly nude martyr or saint stands upon an altar-like platform with arms extended, clad only in a white loincloth. To his right a robed cleric kneels in prayer, hands clasped and head inclined. Center stage is a bishop, wearing a white mitre and green cope with gold-lined edges, holding a long crozier in his left hand and gesturing in veneration with his right. To the bishop’s right stands a monk in a simple brown habit, hands raised in prayer. At far right is an empty sarcophagus or bier, suggesting the translation of relics or an empty tomb. All figures stand on a single ground line against a rich blue background. Dresses and vestments are distinguished by color and cut: the cleric’s brown cloak edged in red, the bishop’s green and cream robes, and the monk’s undyed brown habit. Depth is implied by the slight overlap of figures; scale is uniform. The composition centers on the bishop, distributing visual weight symmetrically.

religious: Nearly nude martyr or saint on platform
Bishop with mitre and green cope

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum with uniform thickness and very smooth, well-pumiced surface; faint hair-follicle pattern visible in margins.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent condition; pigments remain vivid with minimal abrasion. Slight darkening at upper edge and minor flaking in red lines.
notable_physical_characteristics: Fine underdrawing visible beneath brown ink outlines
Plummet ruling for text and image frame evident
No raised gesso or gold leaf present
Uniform red frame executed in pen

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual lay patron of noble rank

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature and text leaf likely originated in a mid-14th-century French workshop specializing in vernacular devotional manuscripts. The use of Old French rather than Latin, together with the modest scale and absence of gold leaf, suggests a commission by a lay patron for private meditation rather than grand liturgical display. The deep azurite ground and restrained palette reflect the influence of the Parisian illumination tradition, while the careful underdrawing and uniform ruling reveal professional studio practices. Iconographically, the juxtaposition of a martyr or saint on an altar with kneeling clerics and a mitred bishop underscores the theme of relic veneration and ecclesiastical authority, common in devotional works that guided personal prayer through visual exemplars of saintly intercession. Stylistically, the flat, nearly abstract treatment of space and the horizontal procession of figures align with contemporary commissions for private Books of Hours, yet the absence of figurative gold leaf indicates a more economical execution typical of second-tier ateliers outside central Paris. Comparisons with dated miniatures in extant manuscripts from the Île-de-France region support this attribution, revealing similar blue grounds and quill-drawn figural outlines. The leaf thus bridges regional illumination practices and evolving private devotional needs, combining clear narrative emphasis with a simplified yet effective decorative scheme.
